solution_line_template: For every acre of grass, the farmer can harvest {last_year_bales}/{last_year_acres} = <<{last_year_bales}/{last_year_acres}={bales_per_acre_per_month}>>{bales_per_acre_per_month} bales of hay each month.
This year, the farmer has {additional_acres} + {last_year_acres} = <<{additional_acres}+{last_year_acres}={total_acres}>>{total_acres} acres of grass.
He can expect to harvest {total_acres} x {bales_per_acre_per_month} = <<{total_acres}*{bales_per_acre_per_month}={bales_per_month}>>{bales_per_month} bales of hay per month.
The total hay production this year is {bales_per_month}*{months_in_year} = <<{bales_per_month}*{months_in_year}={total_bales_this_year}>>{total_bales_this_year}

From September to December, the farmer would have to feed his horses for a total of {sept_days} + {oct_days} + {nov_days} + {dec_days} = <<{sept_days}+{oct_days}+{nov_days}+{dec_days}={feeding_days}>>{feeding_days} days
Each day his horse eats a total of {bales_per_horse_per_day}*{num_horses} = <<{bales_per_horse_per_day}*{num_horses}={daily_bales_consumed}>>{daily_bales_consumed} bales of hay.
For the {feeding_days} days, the horses will eat a total of {daily_bales_consumed}*{feeding_days} = <<{daily_bales_consumed}*{feeding_days}={total_bales_consumed}>>{total_bales_consumed} bales.
The total number of bales remaining will be {total_bales_this_year}-{total_bales_consumed} = <<{total_bales_this_year}-{total_bales_consumed}={bales_remaining}>>{bales_remaining}.
